ezzyis1nQ2eLiBTDXQ8-GA.text: Visited just an hour ago. Great service. Waiters and waitresses are ready to serve you. The food was phenomenal. Order the Katsu-Don. I never had the dish before but it was good. Unfortunately I couldn't finish it. I love how perfect the eggs were. The were perfectly cooked. The facility is clean and it seems to be a bit busy right around lunch but that's to be expected on a Sunday. Will return!

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States

KBsy_6wtHBZ_ASEvr-UPNQ.text: I've been going to Curry Zen to fulfill my Japanese curry cravings and it's probably one of the best spots in Vegas to do so! The curry isn't heavy and leaves me wanting more! I usually get the Tonkatsu Curry for ~$10 and it fills me up! I wish the size of the tonkatsu was just a bit bigger though! I've also tried the 3 piece Kushikatsu (Deep fried zucchini, quail egg, and chicken skewer). I didn't enjoy the kushikatsu as much unfortunately so I probably won't get it again - mostly because the chicken was pretty tough and chewy and it was a lot of quail egg for me to finish lol. The service is always fast and friendly so this is a great place to grab a quick bite!

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious Tonkatsu Curry!

1-Z6xm9cRebI-l9UR7VY4A.text: Curry, anyone?   When you first come here, you cant help but notice the little flyer that is encased in lexan plastic on the table and it is also on the back of the menu. What's on there is all the spices they use and what they are all about. I just sat down and just this info alone I am better for it because I just found out more info on the usual everyday spices I use on my food.  Their menu is pretty simple. Pick your meat whether its Pork, Chicken, Beef, Sausage, etc. You receive your picked meat covered with their special curry they make from scratch along with white rice. I  couldn't make up mind so I chose the Beef but added Pork Cutlet and a Croquette.   I shared this wonderful creation with my wifey and we were both impressed. The Pork was juicy and not dry at all. The Beef was soft and tender. As for the Croqette, I have never had it before so I don't really know how to describe it. It's basically a mashed potato cake with some vegetables in it.   Service was spot on with everything from our order being correctly taken to refills to receiving our check and payment promptly being handled. This was one tip I didn't mind adding extra with the standard.   Overall, just about everything was perfect except for the size of their place. It is pretty small and on really busy nights, you just might have to wait a bit. Oh well, you know what they say, sometimes good things come in small packages and this is one of them.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef Curry with Pork Cutlet and Croquette!

YHitYcF1doTt9XCNASPa9A.text: Hands down the best Japanese curry place in town and their portions are just right. Food is consistently good and very authentic. The staff is attentive and polite as well!

t3X1dgDunNujrNdTbT2Z1w.text: Best curry in town. Hands down. Very genuine Japanese atmosphere when I walk in. The servers are all very nice and always make sure you're being tended to. Their spice levels may differ depending on your tolerance towards spicy foods. I come here all the time and I always leave satisfied!

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Katsu Curry with brown rice, corn and veggies!

I8ytsdMGbiwWNjcKwJkRCA.text: Service 10/10. Took hour seats very quickly and the food served minutes from ordering. Me and my party all order their curry chicken katsu, some takoyaki. "Crispy/crunchy katsu". Tried the level 9 spicy curry but it felt more of a 2-3 but it's okay, spicy game weak anyways. Definitely will return to try the other stuff on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Curry, chicken katsu, sweet corn

1U4FTi1z8AVgNAyOpiMnzg.text: Chicken Katsu all day, baby!  This place is fantastic. Service is quick, food is delicious, and they make a good Thai Ice Tea. Medium spicy was about perfect for me, giving a nice kick but not causing you to sweat your face off.   The only negative about this place is that it's located somewhat far away from the strip where most people spend their time and stay in hotels. But this review is about the food and service, both of which are excellent.

3z7KYQ0OJRx9NRe0Wy7xCw.text: I'm never really a big fan of going out for Japanese curry because it's something that is so cheap and easy to make at home, so my review might be a little harsh. My friend on the other hand is a Japanese curry fanatic and would eat it every day if he could which is why we ended up here. We stopped by this place as we were leaving Las Vegas as just a quick meal before a long drive home. It was relatively empty since we got there not long after they opened. Since there were 4 of us, we decided to each try something different. We started off with 2 appetizers: takoyaki (4/5) and shu mai (1/5). For mains, I got the kushi curry with a croquette (3/5). My friends got the chicken katsu curry (2/5), karage curry (2/5), and pork medallion curry (2/5). You pay a base price for the curry + the meat, but if you want it spicier you add money on depending on the spice level you choose. Considering their prices were already relatively high, I wasn't so keen on the idea of adding more money just for a spicier dish. The takoyaki was very fresh and probably the best thing I had over lunch. The shu mai on the other hand was sad and over fried and definitely not worth the price. All the meat in the curries were super dry and tough. My friend who ordered the pork medallions was surprised at how dried out his pork was considering he ordered medallions in hopes that they would be much more juicy and tender than just a regular pork katsu. Even the karage and chicken were dry. The best curry was by far the kushi, since it came with a variety of things (my personal favorite being the quail eggs), but it definitely was not worth the price in my opinion. Not only did I get less portion wise, but the kushi curry was $2 more than the katsu curries. Definitely would not return here next time around.   Pros:  - Takoyaki was very fresh  - Offer a generous amount of curry sauce - Large interior with a good number of tables  Cons: - Hard to find parking - Meats were all dried out (especially sad considering they are fried) - Prices are way more than I'm willing to pay for something I could make at home for $5 or less

bBDxIHgGZYcLe6kQrCh5Sg.text: Pros-   complex curry taste rich with Indian spices.  Good spice level Attentive waiters and fast Chicken Katsu was on point and flavorful The rice was sticky and nice The Japanese sausage was smoky and bit sweet  Cons-  Cramped seating Waiters too busy to ask if you want dessert The small tvs.   Overall:  Great curry flavor and warm Japanese atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Easy menu
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cozy interior
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Great quantity

TLbabELvb_f0k2c3DS-f4Q.text: Great little spot for Japanese style curry!  Love how you can adjust spice level and the selection of toppings is great.  Usually stick to the pork Katsu curry with a side of steamed vegetables.  The aroma of curry as you enter is quite pungent and gets your appetite going even more.  The pork tender katsu curry is very good but I tend to just gravitate back to the standard katsu curry.  The appetizers are good to try family style especially if you order a curry entree.  Recommendations include the breaded oysters, shumai and gyoza.  These aren't gourmet appetizers per say but they are quite tasty in their own rights.  The owner spends his time in the kitchen preparing dishes so you know you're in good hands during every meal here.  I've seen some people eating the curry udon and would like to try it sometime soon.

VSaG8ZV_fE-eq8MnFxQgNg.text: We were originally shooting for Tofu Hut, but since the Golden Warriors won the NBA Finals... We decided to celebrate in honor of Steph Curry and get some curry (get it?)  My boyfriend has been to this place once before so he pretty much knew right off the bat what he wanted. I stuck to what I knew which was chicken katsu. They have a spice level scale on the bottom right hand of their menu. I can handle a little heat, but not too much - with that being said, I went with a level 3.  I can not be more thankful that I did. A level 3 was just perfect for me and my "heat" palate. It gave my meal a good kick without causing a waterfall dispensing from my nose. I do have to add though that a level 3 here is a lot more spicier than a level 3 in most Thai restaurants that I've ate at. In addition to our meals, we ordered tako yaki. It's good for what it is (octopus balls), but I probably wouldn't order it again since I'm not really a fan of octopus.  If you're a fan of curry, consider this place. It's small, quaint, and the chefs pack a hell of a punch when it comes to spices in your meals.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Level 3 was comfortable for me.
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tako Yaki

NstoAl9_wpAbyT2pgsFx-Q.text: Super-delicious curry spot! Loved the small, easy-to-navigate menu (everything is based around one deeply savory, umami-packed curry with white or brown rice). I went with the Spinach Curry on the Specials board ($7) to keep my dinner light, but ended up getting enough food to take some home!   I really enjoyed the extra curry spices put on the table that allow you to either change or accentuate the spiciness of your meal. Pickled ginger and onions added crunch and an acidic sweetness that made my affordable dinner an experience of flavors.   Service was top-notch, and drinks/alcohol are super affordable. We'll be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spinach Curry special ($7)
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Extra curry on every table :-P

XlLRvHSFxWCUuh7QY5SZhw.text: If you're looking to try some Japanese curry, this is definitely the place. You choose your item and they're going to ask you how spicy on a scale of 1 - 10. I usually get a 1 just because it already gets spicy after a couple bites. I also order their tako yaki which is to die for if you love tako. Also when we eat the curry, don't forget to ask for the red pickles, it somewhat toned down the spiciness. Great customer service as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled chicken curry spicy level 1.

9WgHc0Z8LmhKaxCUp52Lww.text: I have been searching for a curry place in Vegas that I would always enjoy love going to and I have found it at Japanese Curry Zen.   Inside the restaurant is really small and calm, which can be desirable or undesirable, depending on the person I guess, but I don't really see it as a negative thing.   The curry itself is very tasty. When you order, I recommend getting the chicken or pork cutlet. You can even order an extra side of meat or anything else with it because they give you ample curry for another piece of meat! They even have different spices and condiments on the table for you to add to your curry so your curry won't ever be boring!  The owner always says hello and talks to customers when it isn't busy and asks if you are enjoying the food. That little bit of effort he puts to make sure everything is okay goes a long way.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken and pork katsu with brown rice, corn, and cheese

Wl9cqrZj0EHZZClOLZlzcA.text: This curry house is located in a plaza with a couple of my favorite restaurants. When I first came to Curry Zen when it first opened it was super small and only seated a max of maybe 15 people.  They've expanded it since then.  My usual plate it the chicken tender curry original spice WITH a croquette.  The flavors are wonderful and it has a light kick to it but of course you can pick a spicier level.  Sometimes I get the chicken katsu curry but since it has more fat and I'm trying to be more "health conscious" (lol) I stick with the chicken tenders.    I think a must topping to have with curry is cheese, almonds, and raisins.  Traditional and non traditional toppings but still makes it delicious.  I've ordered the fried oysters a couple times, it's good but you can see and taste the oil its fried in so I try to stray away from eating all 3.

bcQvmJsodR9A6KEWRj_1bg.text: Love this place.  Food is very tasty. I had the chicken katsu with a number 7 in spice volume. And a thai tea which was super sweet. Other than the Thai tea being sweet I love this place.  Definitely one of our eating spot when we're in town.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy chicken katsu curry with curry in the side.  Spice volume was a 7.

IFo_o70IQhCA548dyO4Kgg.text: It was a grey, rainy and chilly day in Vegas.. perfect weather for Japanese Curry.  The Tofu Katsu was really wonderful. The curry was just amazing. It was tasty, hot and just the right side of spicy. The restaurant is way off the strip and while small, it was filled late in the afternoon with locals. Thanks Yelp for helping me find this treasure.

lOo_h0cs6SR2ZX47MRHiEA.text: This is one of the Japanese style curry house . The spicy level from 1 to 10. I normally get between 3 to 5 . Chicken Katsu curry is my favor. With a fried oyster ( 3 pieces ) and a drink . Total : $15.68 . The price is fare. For any curry lover this is a good place to go .

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7LuIHrrUk3os3Q0moorsWg.text: I liked it, and would go back. It fell short vs some of the better curry shops i've had in tokyo, but its a nice visit and something a little different vs. a typical vegas restaurant. felt pretty legit.

zW9yAYsnTYDAZSqa1F_LaA.text: Was looking for a late dinner place in Vegas.  I didn't want to do the typical Vegas Strip restaurant and wanted somewhere off-strip.  My group saw this plaza nearby and decided to check it out.  Checking Yelp, Japanese Curry Zen had very high ratings (highest in the plaza) so it must be good and decided to check it out.  When I first went in, a larger group was eating inside and noticed the only seating spots available were at the counter.  I was greeted with the "irashaimasae!" (welcome in Japanese) and was very pleasant to hear.  I ordered the tender pork katsu with a spice rating of 3 which was medium spice.  My wife ordered 5 and it was a little on the spicy side.  Generally if you are novices to curry, I would recommend a 2.  The tender pork was indeed tender and cooked very well.  The curry had a thickness to it and wasn't watered down like some places... it had a good spice kick to it and hands down was one of the best curry I ever had.  Their prices were reasonable and the owner is very friendly and was very humble.  He did mention that they are expanding the restaurant to the now vacant spot next door, so come January/February they will have more seating capacity.  If you are in need of some awesome Japanese curry or something different than the average Vegas Strip restaurant, check this place out!

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Simple menu...I love it

AGYAPBPTQw_ZV6gtus04pw.text: Food is always bomb and hits the spot. I've never been disappointed with an order from here, but I took a star off because the last few times I ordered through a delivery service I recieved a noticeably smaller amount than usual.

YCz96x82oSi4dq65VyM_Iw.text: My friends and I wanted to get a quick bite to eat before we headed back on the road after a long Vegas trip. Monta Ramen had waaaay too long of a line so we decided to give this place a try and I'm so glad we did. I recommend ordering the chicken katsu curry with a level 4 spice. I love spicy food and the 4 was perfect to me. It was still spicy but not overpowering which I really appreciated. My friends ordered the beef curry, pork katsu curry, and tofu curry. They all really liked them too.   Overall, I will definitely be back because I want to try their curry udon. If anyone tries it or has tried it, please let me know how it is but I'm sure it's delicious like everything else here!   Note: while you're in the plaza go to Kung fu tea too! It's great

3q2tib4nEd4qeX6GhHytTw.text: Yes, Yes 1000 times yes. Chicken Katsu with veggies - my go to and a regular craving all day every day.

xUQ2UeX7bckjteRZ4hn-Vg.text: More like 3.5 stars. We got the chicken katsu with curry. The curry was fine, my two spicy wasn't that spicy even though our waitress warned us that it was spicy. Luckily there were pepper shakers on the table. I really like the red pickles that goes with the curry and they give you a lot if you ask for them so, that's a plus. The chicken katasu I got was moist but oddly bouncy? It's hard to describe, it wasn't chewy but it just had an odd bounce to it. I kinda expected some vegetables in the curry. You get a big plate but it's kind of underwhelming.

av7IcZcycxWp3bJm7Aw4xQ.text: So slow. The workers are slow. The wifi is slow. The cell services is slow. The food takes forever to come. Took them 20 minutes to bring water/drinks after being seated.

uO2JugJznCL3kJX6sw6e3A.text: Delicious curry with lots of choices. Very attentive staff. Nice small place with fun atmosphere.

6g9EUNKPlyuR4bNaVPLpQg.text: You can get all your curry craving needs taken care of here... the title says it all.    I got the chicken cutlet curry, (so typical) but paid the extra few bucks for the vegetable curry.  I like that you can add in whatever you want to your dishes a-la-carte.  My roommate added the croquet and corn and cheese to her chicken curry, went all out on that shiz.    You also choose your level of spicyness.  Levels 1-5 are free, levels 6-10 are extra.  I got the level 3 thinking it was like a 3/10, mild.  It was actually pretty spicy!  I had to take breaks and I was chugging a lot of water.  I cannot imagine what the 6-10 tastes like.  Next time I will get the 2 for sure.    Condiments galore... everything you need is right in front of you.  I like to add tons of scallions and pickled radishes to my curry.  I will definitely be coming back, especially cus the weather is cooling down.

PX6wZXS5fxdeMo1mxsX62A.text: Let me tell you; The curry here is absolutely DELICIOUS. I'm fairly picky with curry, and so far out of my choices here in vegas, this one's at the top of my list!  The service is good and friendly. It was my coworkers first time eating japanese curry and she wasn't too sure about her spice level she chose, so the server offered to adjust it for her if she wasn't satisfied! (I like spicy but even level 4 is too spicy for me! I was sniffling the whole time!)  The chicken katsu/tenders and beef is soooo good. As we say in hawaii: onolicious brah! The flavor is much more authentic compared to other places I've tried. The katsu tofu and veggies are a good add on as well. The portions are generous so I usually have some leftovers to take home for my next meal ^_^  The only reason I didn't this place 5 stars is because the prices are more on the expensive side.  Otherwise it's really good and I definitely recommend this place :)

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp tempura and tenders :D
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef and veggie combo
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken katsu+beef combo

0No3vlYTxbaCGQwogu4YbQ.text: Love Japanese Curry. While in Vegas for a solar convention, I thought to check and see if there was any here. I drove out to Japanese Curry Zen and loved the ambiance (on a Sunday night too!). Parking was tough in the parking lot for this strip mall of about 15 Asian restaurants at 5020 Spring Mountain - but I parked on street and walked in which was about an extra 60 feet. Got a table as soon as I walked in although the place was very crowded and folks seemed to be waiting outside. The whole strip mall center was high energy and fun. I ordered the chicken cutlet curry with the seasoning on the spicy side at 7 out of 10. They let you pick your spice level. 7 was pretty edgy. Food was great and service was great too. Manager Utah is fairly young with diligence to spare. Many restaurants I wander into have half as much respect for the clientele. Utah personally attended my table in addition to the waitress - who was a great server on her own. This manager Utah was all over the place but his staff were on it. I loved it so much I then ordered a pork cutlet at spice level 4. The spice level difference was substantial -very mild like I'd hoped for. Japanese Curry Zen is wonderful food and has great service and prices are about $8-10 a plate. Liked it so much, I bought a shirt for $10.

Ycble95QCdiwStZ8OtjFHw.text: When is Debra going to learn? When you see the name of the food they serve in the name of the place, then that is what you should be ordering. I don't know when I am going to learn.  I went with their dish that did not have curry. I can't recall the name right now but it was a pork katsu bowl with rice, eggs, seaweed and ginger. I loved the ginger in the bowl. Barely any seaweed. And the scrambled egg, was somewhere in between cooked and not cooked. No complaints from me though, I thought at first I can dig this.   Then I had to dig out a piece of a hair that was embedded in my pork katsu. It was mixed in with the batter surrounding the pork and it never seemed to end. I didn't complain. I just pushed my bowl to the side and ate no more.  Overall, I left feeling disgusted and sad. Even with the hair experience, me and my coworker said we would return but only to try to the Curry. I am not just not sure how fast that is going to happen for me.

2svZLN4vUGsL3omv2CoJKw.text: Good pork katsu that was lightly breaded and pounded thin. The curry had plenty of depth and quite a bit of heat for a level 2. The rice was a good compliment to balance things out. Needing some sweetness after the heat, I ordered their mango cheesecake after finding out the green tea cheesecake was all out. The cheesecake was somewhat dry, lacking the creaminess of better versions. Japanese restaurants aren't typically known for their desserts, so I'd pass next time but would recommend the katsu, especially if you enjoy a bit of spiciness to your curry.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork katsu ($9.45)
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork katsu ($9.45)
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mango cheesecake

fq7SIISGnmBqbCV78kkCsw.text: OHHH YESS. Give me ALL of the curry. This place has our hearts and is one of our fall-back restauraunts anytime we need some delicious food and wouldn't mind a bit of heat. We have come 3 or 4 times and have had a great experience each time.   Beware, their curry truly is HOT. I can only tolerate a 3-4 out of 10 and I'm no wimp. The heat builds the more that you eat so that by the end of the dish, you have to take a few gulps of water after every bite. The pickled vegetables on the side help with the heat, as does added cheese and corn, but nothing will help you if you order a level 10 heat. Nothing... Your insides will be your outsides and I pity the fool that plays like that!  Anyway, if you're a pro with hot curries, I would go with a level 6 or 7 and work from there. They have shakers on the side with curry powder and chile powder to add.   I personally recommend their croquette as it is so fluffy and crispy and delightful, no regrets. If you are a vegetarian or avoid meat, their tofu katsu is perfectly crisp and tastes great with the dark sauce in the squeeze bottles at the table.   I always get the 16 grain curry because I really love the varying texture of the rice. My boyfriend is a fan of the plain white rice with his curry. He normally gets the pork katsu but has tried the Japanese meatloaf before. He wasn't the hugest fan of it but he did like it, just not as much as the pork! ^_^  Overall, you could go to Curry Zen every day of the week and try something new, with amazing service each time to boot! This is definitely one of my favorite places for food on Spring Mountain and I think anyone that likes curry will love Curry Zen :D

xX-EciQSnnrhRUjd360mJw.text: This is one of my top favorite food places in Vegas. I love getting the curry katsu with extra pickled radish on the side-- the pickled radishes really make it for me. I'll often find myself even getting deliveries from here through postmates to my work. And the price is really decent! I only wish there was just a little more chicken in the serving.

xERVGnZmIhBZUYLk1LaWYg.text: Simple concept. Choose your curry. Heat level and whether you want spinach, veggie, or plain curry. Choose your heat level, I went with 5 and it was pretty spicy. I can handle heat and it was perfect for me. Choose your meat and add your sides. I was surprised they didn't serve gyoza and didn't have the meat combinations set up together but you can just add it on if you want. If you haven't had curry it's like spiced gravy but thicker. Very delicious and comforting. You can also choose white or brown rice which is a nice option. This parking lot gets packed so if you can't find a spot park on the street next to the parking lot and walk over not a long walk but this place gets packed since Monta, Raku and Kung du tea are just some of the places with heavy traffic. Thinking of curry is making me crave some. Good thing we keep it stocked in my house. Probably gonna make some now ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried Oysters minus 1 that he ate :/
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Katsu
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Zucchini Kushi

PZqfg5jau7mmPidwFJAyBw.text: Needing a fix for Japanese curry, one that I've had since spending 6 months in Japan a few years ago, I'm glad I finally stopped in.  Chicken Katsu was excellent, added cheese with a side of pickled radish.  Curry was great and the spice level I ordered was just the right amount of pop(#5), chicken was crispy and moist,  and servers were knowledgeable and friendly.  Def recommend!

MFM51STvt88-nNzMW2zbVw.text: Delicious! I heart Japanese curry, and though it's so easy to make it also goes great with everything! This place is super tiny and challenging if you're opting to accommodating a large party, but the food is homestyle goodness. I ordered the 5-piece kushiage. So I got: quail eggs, chicken, shrimp, shiitake, and zucchini, fried on a stick all smothered with curry. I also added fried spam on top. No it's clearly not for the health guru, but it's definitely for the hearty! Their spice level is from 1-10. I was a little worried so I went for level 4, but I wish I went atleast to 7. It's not as spicy as Japan's curry so don't be afraid!

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 5-piece kushiage with spam. Delicious!

3ckD2PjppUZwf0zFsGby6g.text: I like curry, but it was never something I thought about on my own or craved. When I came here, I actually wasn't sure what my expectations were because I know so many people who absolutely love this place, yet I wasn't sure how convinced I was since I'm not exactly a curry enthusiast.   However, here I am, thinking about how much I want to eat it again every day since I went (about 4 days ago).   I ordered a standard chicken katsu curry spice level 3. It was the perfect level of spice for me and I enjoy spicy food. No toppings were added besides the house picked radish.   The katsu itself was delicious and had the perfect crunch. The curry was flavorful and warmed by body and the radish added a nice crunch. The meal overall just felt like comfort food. Even though I know it's part of the aesthetic, my only complaint is that I wish the curry wasn't layered over part of the katsu. I like the crunch of the katsu and layering the curry over it makes it soggy. But that's just a personal preference, like I don't really enjoy nachos because I dislike the sogginess. I'm more of a dipping type of person haha.   Service was super friendly and food came out quick. Now I understand what the hype was all about!

JdwlGheAltnukf1LPmJytA.text: Glad this place is getting more recognition.   Nothing fancy schmancy about this place. Very simple yet clean decor. Serves traditional Japanese curry.   But...Undoubtedly thee best curry I've ever had the pleasure of eating. Their curry is just bursting with flavor, and you can taste all the spices that they incorporate into it. Oishii! Their pork katsu and fried shrimp have always been perfectly crisp as well.  Their service is always superb and accommodating. Arigatou gozaimashita!  Family run business that are just awesome people.   I will always make a trip to this joint whenever I'm back in town :)

fskW_pbtswoXaQ04yIABuA.text: This restaurant has become a quick #1 restaurant in Vegas for me and my fiancee. Although it may not be as fancy or expensive as other restaurants, you can tell the owner's passion for food. I always get the Chicken Katsu Curry and my fiancee's go-to is the Curry Udon. They seem like very simple dishes, but no other places can do the same. Every bite is just full of food-godly goodness. Give it a try, you won't regret it

FGeCDS2lgxNDcPIbjSUbgA.text: Always enjoying here. Friendly staff with fast-service food I would definitely bring my friends back here to check it out. I haven't tried the SW area curry zen but I'm sure its the same quality.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tofu salad, chicken katsuyama, curry udon
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Ijfx6YAxIy4Ro408yPq3YQ.text: I love the food here. I wish they would expand because this location is often crowded. If you come on the weekend for dinner, you will have to wait, without a doubt. To me, it's worth the wait because the food is consistent, it's delicious, and very affordable.   My favorite is the Japanese meatloaf, and I usually order it with spinach. If I'm feeling extra hungry, I'll order an egg on top.   I ordered the meatloaf with mixed vegetables tonight, which was the first time I've had the vegetables, and I didn't love it. I'll stick to my usual.  I love the food at this place, especially on chilly days, or when I feel like going into a food coma. If you don't want to wait, order it to go. It's sill amazing.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Japanese meatloaf with mixed vegetables.

w7qd0y0p2ezFOgvB66bZFg.text: Curry/Katsu has got to be one of the most simple and delicious meals out there.   I ordered:  TOFU KATSU- It was between this or the shrimp Katsu for me and I'm definitely glad I got the tofu! Being a pescatarian there wasn't much options but I didn't mind because I was fine with tofu, shrimp, and the potential option of adding on items. I got a spiciness level of 5 which wasn't too bad at all. The flavors were perfect and the amount of rice to tofu to sauce ratio was amazing!   CUSTOMER SERVICE- The service was a bit slow but the food made up for it.

iYxzkkkHcDHwQp-LbOABDg.text: The fact that you can choose the spicy level for your curry demonstrates how serious they are about their food. I did find the prices to be a bit steep especially since you'll be adding at least one protein option and one topping to any curry order.   The *Zen Curry* I ordered with pork katsu and a fried egg did end up being ~$12. Yes, they do charge 20 cents for every level of spicyness. I happened to select a Level 1 since the waiter did inform me that even a Level 0 would have *some* chili powder added. However, the 1 actually was pretty mild even for someone as intolerant to spice such as myself. The sauce was creamy, rich, and aromatic. Rice was fluffy and the chopped cutlet pieces were juicy and crunchy. I may have complained about the pricing, but you do get A LOT, not just of rice and sauce, but the protein serving was rather large too. I also ordered Takoyaki; I want to say there were six decently sized balls with an even more decently sized dicing of octopus on the inside. These were definitely cooked in a griddle -- there was some crunch on the outside and it was a bit soft and only slightly runny on the inside. Traditional takoyaki is very runny and soupy, so they seemed to have catered a bit to American palate by keeping things mostly firm. I certainly wasn't a fan of traditional takoyaki and I guess I prefer it more solid. Someday, I'll develop a liking for the soupy, traditional kind.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Takoyaki ($4.50)
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Zen curry ($6.95), add pork katsu ($3.50) and a fried egg ($1.50) at level 1 spicy ness ($0.20)

nBC8KGfB08iduOAtbP5U6A.text: So I would come back for the croquettes. And the pork katsu. And the chicken katsu. And the curry. Oh and the rice. Yeah. I'd come back for all of it. Or yah, I'd just come back.

C4VAwibdo7ofO4LirCakow.text: Delicious food. Super fast service. Love the meal. Reasonable prices. Ice cold beer. Great experience

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef curry with vegetables, brown rice and fried egg. Spice level 9. 9 was not too hot. Just right for me.

X5uHxzJ3fOhdhJGBIsj9HQ.text: Pretty good curry overall. The fried oysters were actually our favorite, but overall the food hit the spot. Don't expect anything fancy. Service was great, friendly and quick. Had the pork katsu with curry over rice, level 6, has a little kick but not too over the top.

QdkTQ_OpzmdUzeDMJhPfpg.text: I've been going to Curry Zen for several years now. It's a great place to get delicious curry.  You choose a base ingredient for your curry and then, you can add extra toppings if you like. You also choose the level of spiciness; I usually get Zero Spicy Level since I'm weak against spiciness.  I normally order a Scrambled Egg & Spinach Curry with a Croquette, but last time I went, I ordered a Croquette Curry with Scrambled Eggs and Cheese. Tomato comes with the Scrambled Eggs. They also have other food such as Curry Udon, Naan Bread, and etc. I really enjoy their Takoyaki~ The Takoyaki has a nice crunchy, but soft texture.  You can also choose to order a half curry plate which are smaller than the normal plate at Curry Zen. It's in the same area as Monta, Kungfu Tea, Hwaro, and Sweet Raku.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States

RRouhX2iteZLAdqlNBpTPw.text: Chinatown is known to have a lot more than just Chinese cuisine -- Japanese, Thai, Vietnamese, and so on. And sometimes, even those have different types of food depending on what you're in the mood for! Curry Zen is an example of such a place, focusing specifically on the Japanese comfort food of curry rice. It's a simple dish of curry and rice, but the number of toppings you can choose means you can customize it to be your own! This is another one of my personal favorite places for food in Chinatown.  Whenever I come in, I typically order a large plate of curry rice and an appetizer -- in this case, the mix fry, which is fried shrimp, chicken skewer, croquette and tofu with a salad and a honey mustard sauce. For me, this is the perfect plate to prime my stomach for the curry to come.  And is it a good plate! The curry comes as a rich sauce plated with a snowy mound of rice -- and you can add what you want or make it as spicy as you want! I usually stick with 2 because you can taste the spices and their afterburn even at such a low level. For me, I usually add a lot of toppings for a satisfying meal -- for this review, I went with pork tenderloin, cheese, boiled chicken and shrimp. And I don't regret it -- you just can't stop eating this curry! Adding the pickled red ginger as a side also provides tart refreshment from the savory curry sauce.  It's been seven years since Curry Zen established itself here in Chinatown, and their flavor is one of the many reasons why I and other repeat customers love to come out here for its comforting flavor. A warm hug compared to the typically chilly sushi we think of with Japanese cuisine, if you want something different come here to Curry Zen! You won't regret it.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Their mix fry appetizer. 5/5 -- the salad is a nice touch!
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Their curry rice with toppings and pickled ginger. So good -- 5/5!

CH1XczaH2l7wEJ8q7ip9Cw.text: Probably a 3.5 for me. Good not great. Best thing was the price, very reasonable for the portions, and their wide selection on their menu -many kinds of proteins to add to your curry and a large selection of appetizers/side dishes.  I ordered the katsu curry and shared an appetizer of takoyaki.   The waitress kindly pointed out that their "heat scale" is skewed towards the hotter side, so a 4/10 actually had a decent kick to it. I like things hot, but more mild than my husband. So, I'd get a 3 next time. For reference usually order the "original hot" wings at Wing Stop (though they're a bit milder than my limit). My husband likes things decently spicy, and would have chosen a 5/10 here. (He likes the atomic hot at wing stop).  We had to specifically ask to get the pickled radish that I'd normally expect to come standard with curry. And the sauce was not as tangy (sweet/sour) as I personally enjoy. This is why I wouldn't give them a higher score.

3_3zvRkqLeT7gNMjGga45g.text: Always nice to see a Japanese restaurant with actual Japanese workers in it!  I love katsudon and it was spot on here! Takoyaki reminded me of the street vendors in Kyoto. Excellent. Haven't tried the curry yet, but will give it a go next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Katsudon &amp; Takoyaki

3yNy5S951YVNgiVsbzk_yg.text: I love Japanese curry. When I saw the reviews for this place I went to check it out, and I got there just in time. Once it hit noon, there was a line down the outside of the building. It's a small place, so most likely you will have to wait. I did the "create your own curry" option. I ordered chicken Katsu with vegetables curry. It was so good, and I got a low spice level of 3, still a tad spicy. I'll probably go with a 1 next time lol. I like spice, but also want to enjoy my food. Service is fast and friendly.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ICIhpyuhv38Z1eDZTXKG2A.text: It's always a delight to comeback to curry zen. Not only is the staff very friendly the service is quick and attentive. This may be subject to personal biased but I believe it bears Coco's any day. I've had Cocos in Japan, korea and LA and nothing is like Zen. I'm so glad they opened one on the north side to feed my low key addiction

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Double chicken katsu curry with spinach . Spicy 5 Chicken Katsu Curry

8A1O0xEH5ABIedn-HG9LWQ.text: Curry was delicious and exactly what I needed after finding out I had broken my toe. Even on a hot summer day this curry hits the spot. I got it at a spice level 5 which was perfect for me, my crazy friend got a spice level 10 and is still alive so I guess hers was okay too. Reasonably priced and fantastically seasoned. 10/10 would recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef curry

vNSXAj_weOn73Mig5CX7gg.text: Chicken Katsu curry with an egg and cheese!  It's well worth it.  Spice level 2-3 is kinda mild so if you're looking for a kick try to get a 4-5+

AhAs0CBcEmNwkLP5KsO8ZQ.text: Had a quick lunch today, simple menu and fast services. This place filled up pretty quick during lunch so b ready. Customer here dont sit that long either so waiting for table also doesnt take that long. I ususally come here once or twice a month. i think i tried the whole menu already and my fav probably Oyakodon.

gv-f9iG7LjmSyUW4fuac1Q.text: I love curry zen. They have the best Japanese curry in town. I remembered when they first opened. The owner used to man the kitchen and you can tell that he was very passionate about what he does. It shows in how good the food is here. My go-to here is the chicken katsu. I like to change up my extra toppings. Sometimes I get it with spinach, sometimes scrambled eggs, sometime cheese; depending on how I'm feeling. I always eat my curry with the pickled ginger and Japanese shallots. It adds an extra crunch to the food. Food is definitely five stars. Service used to be better. As a person who used to be a server, it irks me to see people waiting at the front door without getting greeted. I watched one of the servers walk past and ignore the person maybe 5 times and eventually walks behind him to reach for the waitlist, STILL, without acknowledging his presence. I understand it's busy but at least acknowledge the waiting guest and let them know you'll assist them later. Also it took a couple asks to get the pickled sides too. Oh well! Hopefully service improves! I'll definitively keep coming back here because it's still one of my favorite spots to eat at.   Service needs improvement.

OhNHqoU_HGlDq11ZEKT3AQ.text: Last year, this restaurant ignited my unknown love for Japanese curry and now I can't get enough of it. It is a blessing and a curse that I hate the parking situation of the plaza it's in or else I would be eating here far too often. The parking lot has the potential of being a pain based on the hour of the day; however, the food here is definitely worth.  It's a cozy, small restaurant. There have been times when there's a wait; however, the maximum time that I've waited was fifteen minutes and a majority of the time, we were seated immediately. Please note that every time that I've been here, it was for lunch. The service is always super friendly and fast!  I can't lie and say that I've tried and loved everything on the menu simply because I order the same thing every single time - chicken katsu curry with the spice level at three. The portion is fair and fills me up about halfway through the meal. The chicken is crispy and goes so, so well with the curry sauce and rice. You can pick and choose your toppings with their popular ones being corn and cheese, but I love a fried egg on top!   I would definitely give this place a try whether you're an avid curry lover or it's something that you've never had!

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1b7852En6uhmYPXY5b88sw.text: Nothing brings me so much comfort than Japanese Curry. As I had Japanese Curry for the first time in Hawaii. Thats where I was introduce to have curry with cheese. The plaza is packed with other amazing restaurants. So this place probably will have space to seat. Parking might be a challenging depending on the time of day. Service was good, my table had just enough service which is always nice. The Curry quality was so good. I got a spicy level 3 and it was perfect. They had my usual curry order which is beef curry with cheese, a hint of spice. So that was super exciting as I haven't had curry at a curry restaurant in foreverrrrrrr. If you want some more spice they have the spicy pepper to give that extra heat. They also had appetizers too which I got to try the takoyaki and chicken karage. Both super good with flavor.  Love the curry and the appetizers. A place I look forward going to when visiting Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef curry with cheese. Level 3 spice

Ki0Ck9Eykjg4PEXFMS2JPg.text: Best curry in town. Always order chicken tender curry with brown rice topped with fried egg and cheese. I always get spicy level 10 and don't usually have a problem, but I have a high tolerance. I recommend start around 4 or 5 and working your way up.   This place is pretty popular so get there early if you are going for lunch or be prepared to wait (it's worth it!)

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cleaned my plate
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Tender Katsu w/Fried Egg and Cheese (Spicy Level 10)

0jLX1NXuDfpKwU3-OBGntg.text: Visiting for a business trip,  friend told me to try this out when I got a chance. Was glad I did. Super bomb.  I got the chicken katsu spicy level 6.

O3YVxImcTKPXjM8P4xcSvg.text: I remember they would have potato and carrot chunks in their curry, but I went there a few days ago and there was none of that. It was my favorite part! The service from this particular visit was not good and also slow. On the other hand, the portions are large and will definitely fill you up.   When I came this time, I asked for level 10 spicy on my pork katsu curry but it wasn't as spicy as I was hoping it would be. The pork also tastes like the chicken... weird.   Anyway, I don't think I would suggest that my friends and I go here if we were ever in a pickle to find a place to eat, but I wouldn't mind going here again if I had to.

nSRJFVv1nYjI4_xi0MbPdQ.text: 2nd time trying Japanese curry in my life!! Recommend by my boyfriend and my supervisor at work. Not a huge curry fan so I was scared I wasn't going to eat when I came here...I actually did enjoy the food. We went on a week day evening wasn't busy at all. We got sat right away, ordered within a few minutes, and our food came out shortly after. I shared a plate with my bf and we ordered curry with pork & chicken Katsu, vegetables at spicy level3. I probably would come back again and have my own plate! I wouldn't order vegetables though since they do charge $3 extra for that.

W_AqMN6w9C-x9iyslyOeIQ.text: Given that it was Las Vegas, this was a decent place to get good Japanese curry and Italy oyako donburi bowl. We went late on Saturday night. The place was busy but we took ours to-go. It was ready fairly quickly. The regular curry was a tad spicy so proceed with some caution if you are wimpy!

KBqFH3IEpI70tzpKQH2XxQ.text: This is literally my favorite place to eat. Not joking. I can come here literally everyday and not get sick or tired of it. If I could, I would eat curry for breakfast lunch and dinner  the service is great as well. The parking sucks but the food is worth waiting for. I only go here for Japanese curry... nowhere else. I've been coming here for years now, my best friend actually took me here my first time and fell in love with the food. I have only tried their curry up to levels 1-6, not bad actually it's tasty! Love spicy food. The curry pan is amazing! The appetizers are delicious!  Edit: update! Recently went, and I'm very disappointed in the change of the curry portion. They used to fill the whole plate. Very disappointed. Please go back to the old portion.

tQxdy54i0_NF7qG3WhO2qQ.text: I once tried Curry Zen (when it first opened) and was thoroughly unimpressed. So unimpressed that I forgot I had been here already! This is no surprise because I'm notoriously anti-fried food and need greens with every meal. However, after visiting Japan this summer I am all about the curry and kushiage life now.  SERVICE & LOCATION Quick and friendly service, as with any respectable Japanese curry place. I would be annoyed if they were fancy and asked me about my day! Just tryin' to shovel some spice level 5 in without small talk. The venue itself is pretty plain and unassuming, and a tad bit cramped. Being located in one of the busiest plazas in Vegas makes parking a headache during peak hours.  FOOD Ahh, the star of the show is of course their curry. Fragrant, filling, and can be made to an obnoxiously spicy level. (They charge you above level 2, I think). You can customize it with toppings or choose from premade sets. I personally like vegetable curry with potato croquette! (I heard you liked carbs, so we took carbs, wrapped it in carbs... deep fried!)  Chicken kushiage is kind of dry but the zucchini is delicious. Oh, and the side salad is somehow super addicting.   This place is perfect if you're really hungry (huge portions). If you have a small appetite, like my mother, you can totally split a plate with some other weenie.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Vegetable curry spice 5 with croquette!

vQnTmFZqDsGVAQb6dVXHmA.text: I have lived in Okinawa , Japan. Where I fell in love with a curry house called Coco's, as a child. It has legit been years since I've come close to curry that tastes like that ! This place is EVERYTHING !!! I truly recommend this place to everyone !!

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States

va6MaOQWQ3FgTwAInN4HTA.text: Great food and the best curry I have had in Vegas. Curry is great for any craving that you may have. The staff is super nice and friendly although they can get a little busy and ignore you sometimes.   My go to are the meatloaf and beef curries. The tonkatsu is classic and great as well. Pretty much anything mixed with curry you can't go wrong.

AlppS9e35sXgKL1onw-2fg.text: Curry house serving up some amazing curry with spice adjustments and bunch of topping options from chicken katsu to meat loaf. Located in the same plaza as Raku, Monta Ramen and Kung Fu Tea.   SERVICE Every worker I have encountered have been polite and attentive. Quick to refill water, get your order and checks. Customer service here is on point everytime.   FOOD I grew up eating curry. Back when I was living in Japan, I remember I always looked forward to my school lunch every Friday because it was curry rice. I looked forward to it so bad I couldn't even pay attention in class. 1+1=curry? Makes sense.    Keep in mind, curry is one of those things where everyone makes it differently and each household has different style of curry. Japanese curry has evolved in many ways because people are constantly trying to figure out ways to make it taste better- adding chocolate or coffee in curry is typical in many Japanese households.   All of that somewhat irrelevant information aside, it's difficult to rate a curry for me because I am accustomed to my family's homemade curry. I do have to say the curry here is good in its own way. I know Mr. Zenbayashi takes pride in his curry and I enjoy the curry here, with spicy level 0 because I can't handle any spicyness. I also like mine with chicken katsu and cheese. Don't go too crazy on the spicy level as some find level 2 to be pretty spicy. There's also extra charge if you go past 6 on the spice scale.   I appreciate that they offer many options. You can get your curry with brown rice, white rice or udon. They also offer chicken katsu, pork katsu, meat loaf, kurobuta sausage, cheese, corn, croquette, fried shrimp etc. (Anywhere from $.50 to $3.00 to add-on). Customize your way!  CONCLUSION The portion is somewhat small but for the price range of $10-12, their rich and thick curry with crispy and perfectly fried katsu is well worth it.

oLv5wdm7PIUp5v68EdbbXg.text: I live very near to a Coco's AND a Curry House. Yet, I find myself abstaining for months when I plan to go to Vegas. This place is the most delicious curry I have ever had.

y48paekFpO4UUY28LYW6Xg.text: This was the first place I ever had Japanese curry. I ordered the chicken katsu curry with a croquette and cheese, spice level 10. I really enjoyed the flavours much more than Thai curry. The curry itself had nice spices and the cheese complemented it well. The level 10 was a little spicy, but I could definitely use a bit more kick. The chicken katsu looked amazing and tasted much like how it looked. The croquette was merely ok to me, so I'll probably skip that next time.   Service was quick and my water never got more than half empty. Prices were fair, I think it was just under $25 for my friend and I. I'll definitely be back the next time I get a curry craving.

POYy1DzssRVSYXhltpMhbg.text: Japanese Curry Zen is a curry house in the China town area that offers a delicious base curry served with your choice of meat, spice level, and sides! I've only tried one other curry house in Las Vegas and they have my favorite sauce here. Saying this curry is like the store boat curry would be like saying the ramen you buy at a grocery store is like Monta.  They serve white and brown rice with many different proteins to go with your curry & rice like katsu'd pork/chicken, spam, sausage, meat loaf, croquettes, beef, and grilled chicken. Some other add ons are cheese, corn, and veggies. They also have some sides like fried oysters, gyoza, and curry puffs.  I got the chicken katsu curry and added veggies, corn, and cheese. I'm a sucker for a Japanese meat patty so I got one of those on the side too. Be careful because all of the sides can add up! My dinner wound up being about $18 with a water lol.  The food was delicious! Both proteins I got were cooked very well. The katsu chicken was moist on the inside & the Japanese meatloaf was flavorful and delicious. The cheese  I got added a creaminess that made the dish for me. I've never had cheese on my curry but will probably always get it that way in the future.  My one gripe would be my assumption that a 5 on their spice level would be medium. It was HOT. I would have enjoyed my dinner more had I got a lower spice level. I did try my friends 1 spice and it was a bit sweet for me so I'm sure a 3 would be solid.  The service was good. It was sweet of them to happily split our bill even though it was super busy.   I'll definitely be back but I'll tone it down on the add-ons and get a lower spice level.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious plate of food! $8.95 curry but added on many extras!

9jkEutS60O1WNxPELbCARQ.text: Curry Zen is always going to be my favorite Japanese Curry Place. The parking is tough. The Restaurant is located in a small plaza with a bunch of other good places to eat. The service is always quick and the servers are very nice. I'm always getting regular curry with brown rice with spam. Get the Japanese pickles and a curry pan!

RX3w5QrsdqQ1noBWiHm4Aw.text: SOLID Japanese curry restaurant but we weren't  wowed by our dishes   ---pork katsu with curry (spicy level 5): it wasn't too spicy, honestly more of a mild to medium spice level. The curry was good but the katsu was a bit dry, I expected a fattier cut   NOTE: love how they offer to put everyone's food on separate bills and take credit cards

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork katsu curry

yT0CY1dBxrfjq6AfwcjuUQ.text: We had the fried oyster and udon. It was really good.  We also ordered the chicken katsu over rice.  We got different levels of spiciness. The level 5 was pretty spicy for someone that can't take spice.  The service was a little slow.  If they had one more waiter then we don't have to wait.

JlugSMLUlnzfIEN7vClzJA.text: Maybe I'm not the best person to be writing this review, as curry isn't my favorite, but I enjoyed my experience so I will comment on that.  I ordered chicken katsu with the lowest level of spice. The chicken was really good and the curry wasn't spicy! I definitely could have done a couple levels higher, so if you don't like spice get level one. I also tried some of my boyfriends tofu katsu which was good as well. I usually have tofu with peanut sauce, but the tofu katsu went well with curry!  The service was great! They were very attentive and checked on us often. The restaurant is kind of small, so I can see there being a line if it was earlier on in the evening (we went around 9pm or so).

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Katsu

l1LOs2EA0sE-GP_uUWe1Hw.text: What I remember about living in Japan was the soba trucks they had the best curry and this place is the closest to reliving those moments

xDSPEt7Gb4oTJuKpdHWnRg.text: IM AN SO ADDICTED TO THIS PLACE ITS CRAZY! Absolulty love the curry they put on! And for me I can't handle spice AT ALL but here I can get a number 1 or 2 spice level and be completely fine! Their resultant is a little small but cozy. The food, or the fried chicken in the chicken katsu curry makes up for it and the horrible parking lot! We had to park across the street at the church just to eat here!

BXddXbsRjVxjKea-VZ8v8w.text: The curry was very authentic. Service was very good as well. We were out of town and I was craving some good Japanese food. We all get sushi and Japanese BBQ everywhere. However, to get a good Japanese Curry place was a very unique thing especially in Vegas. You guys should start something in Little Tokyo in LA. The food was delicious. The spice level was proper, the chicken was cooked perfectly.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. This is the curry I was talking about...but oops its pretty much gone in my tummy!

wlcx5yXzJ2E7TC8aiUIWbQ.text: I LOVE THIS PLACE. BEST curry house in Vegas.  The menu is simple but it's delicious! I come here so often that the servers know my order by heart. If you want to eat at a good curry house, you have to visit this place.

dlXSKBuhHUsP-XgdsppTdQ.text: Great curry, we go there almost every week for our curry supply.  Favorite dish is the chicken Katsu which is well cooked and matches with the chicken flavored curry.  Rice is easy and plentiful.  I have tried the Curry Udon as well and would recommend that too.  Overall it doesn't have a lot of variety but what it does make it makes it really good.

GOwJak7qVbCbBZ2N8XhACQ.text: Now I know why this place is so popular! It's just very straightforward. There are several appetizers, and a few different options for your curry--meat, vegetables, tofu, spice level, cheese, what have you... I like the tofu curry as well as the vegetable curry! Good flavor, and it definitely hit the spot!

lThSuT12sSJ6tud-ExznmA.text: This place is on the rotation whenever my wife and I are in Vegas. I haven't really had that much Japanese curry, but it is damn good here.

UOsb4TThWlI0HKa__EkgNA.text: I love, love, love this place! Since the first check in just over a month ago, I can't get enough of it. Everything that I love about a restaurant is here and aligns perfectly like a balance of the universe. I swear, the stars align when I visit this place!  - I love how the place is so small and cozy; the capacity is only 18 people.  - The prices are very affordable with the base price starting at $4.95. - The menu is simple and easy to breeze through - You can customize your curry: toppings? spiciness? brown rice? They got it! - The food is delicious, fresh and doesn't weigh a person down. It's pretty healthy too, so that feeling of "I ate pretty good," resonates through my head instead of, " I can't believe I ate _that_. I think I'll go hibernate now."  Finally, the owner and his staff are some of the nicest most appreciative people that I have met. I have been here 4 times now and the gentleman behind the counter (I believe he's the owner) always takes the time to greet guests entering the restaurant as well as thanking them as they exit. If you're up at the bar eating, he'll most likely ask you personally how everything was. The rest of the staff are warm and attentive too. This really hits it home for me because it shows that the owner really cares about his restaurant and the customers.  Curry Zen gets 5 stars from me because I honestly can't get enough of it. Whether it's the next day, whether I'm on the other side of town, or whether it's four in the morning, it always sounds good. My boyfriend is also a big fan and jokes that they must put crack in it ;)  So if the line at Monta is a little long, try swinging by this little gem and giving it a go. You might find your Zen here ^_^

vCv3MQEUywSo0IIn5qoRVw.text: One of my favorite foods when I lived in Japan was curry. I love so many different Japanese dishes but that is the one thing that is pretty hard to find in many places in the U.S. I was thrilled to find Japanese curry zen. For anyone who's had Japanese curry I assure you this place is exactly what you are looking for if you have that craving, and  for anyone who has never had it before it's definitely worth it to try some new delicious Japanese food.

PKlI7kLVMiVS92yZ0BZxNQ.text: I love me some Japanese curry, so finding a delicious one is key.  My boyfriend and I used to go to a Japapnese curry place in Manhattan a lot during the few months that we lived there called Go-Go Curry. They perhaps had the best Japanese curry I had ever tasted, so when we left NY, that was one of the few restaurants we thought would be hard to replace, until we found Zen Curry.  Now, the flavor is pretty spot on to our favorite curry joint in NY, only suggestion for Zen curry would be to add a little shredded cabbage to the plate. You'd be amazed what that added texture will do for the overall experience.  This place is definitely my favorite in THIS city!

v1hpNx-ec0MwfFu_AJUfdg.text: You are what you eat........eat Zen!  I happened to be at this place on the opening day. I was actually planing to eat at Big Wong when I looked across the parking lot and saw the new place with a grand opening sign so I decided to try it. The place was packed! All the tables were taken,(all 2 of them) yes is a small place and you may have to wait outside for your table, so I sat at the bar which I didn't mind because you can see everything that's going on on the kitchen. (Cooks making curry) I ordered the shrimp curry, And even though I'm not a real fan of any curry since the strong taste/flavors seem to revisit me all through the day, like a meal that keeps on giving, but the flavors of this curry weren't too overpowering, just enough to create that indescribable and addictive flavor. The curry is made with more than ten ingredients that the menu claims that every spice or condiment used for this curry contains some holistic health benefit. (Almost as good as snake oil) So you know that every bite is good for your health on top of being good for your taste buds which is actually what counts at the end.      I also had the small salad  which it was crisp and flavorful and at the end of the meal the coffee jello dessert which it was good, again, not too sweet but sweet enough to call it dessert. Can't wait to try the one other dessert.  I left that place feeling good and healthy. Service was great and place was spotless, I guess it had to do with being the grand opening, but I'm pretty sure service will continue to be that way, the place is too small to miss you, you can literally grab your waiter from where you're sitting anytime you need something.  So if you happen to be in the area close to this shopping center that's quickly becoming little Japan, stop and visit this new member of the family, after all we all need a little zen in our lives.                                                                                                    ........or curry.

photos.caption: Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cheap :)
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Coffee jello
Photo of Japanese Curry Zen - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tea

R1tCOAupNuYeWdiEpI3jfg.text: I just went to their pre-opening and I loved it! I can't wait to take my husband because I know he will love it, too!  Their curry  reminds me of  a famous Japanese curry chain called CoCo Ichiban, which is my favorite curry restaurant in Japan.  I had chicken katsu (chicken cutlet) curry, which was always my favorite at CoCo.  Their secret curry sauce is prepared from scratch, and I was so impressed that theirs was as good as CoCo's! I had been missing this so much!  Along with basic curry,  you can add toppings of your choice from chicken cutlet, pork cutlet, deep fried shrimp, croquette, yakiniku beef, sausage and more. I always like chicken katsu on my curry, but other people were saying pork katsu was good, too. I think the spice level is about 4 out of 10, not too spicy, not too mild, but you can add more spice if you like.  The price was reasonable. Curry with 1 or 2 toppings(which I think is enough), is less than $10. Sometimes Japanese portions are too small, but theirs was big enough and I felt very satisfied after the meal.   If you're missing real Japanese curry, or if you 're disappointed with others, this is the one you should try!

XZo5jXreEemphITqFeJrbg.text: I'm sure the shopping center where Curry Zen is located has now become a mini japan town. With the addition of curry, the japanese menu is just about complete for this area.  The restaurant itself is small but very cozy. Got the pork cutlet with croquette. Both were done very well and the curry tasted delicious too. total came to around $11-12 which I guess is reasonable. I actually kinda wished the curry came with some vegetables already in it because just the sauce seems kind of... too simple for me. I guess for its price, I expected more. Overall, service was excellent and I'm actaully hoping they will add more variety to the menu.

nkv5Z_RsQJHuMM85WxpC0w.text: I've been hearing about how good this place is from my friends and all that, so I decided to go eat with them here for the first time ! Upon entering, I was amazed how tiny the place is. We were all greeted in Japanese and we were all seated at the counter seats. Luckily there were seats for all 6 of us because people had to wait to get seated because the place is pretty small.  The waiter was a super nice dude; his name was Yuta or something? Anyways, he had such a happy tone and he was really kind. The chef himself was a very nice man. I was surprised he was the only cook, but he had someone in the back preparing the rice and the plates.   The inside of the place is pretty nice despite it being small. Apparently they changed the menu design and it looks way better now, but I've never seen the old one so whatevs. The counter had a plethora of lucky cat decorations and other cute Asian stuff. I couldn't stop staring at the Asian cat that's swaying back and forth with bells in its hand, yeahhh I get distracted easily.   I ordered the chicken katsu and I switched it to brown rice instead of white and it was not even a problem. Needless to say, it was some damn good curry. Add some of the spices and condiments to it too, it became even more damn good. I wasn't feeling like eating curry too before I got my plate, but once I tasted all the exotic spices I added with the raisins, almonds, and the other stuff, man I was sad when the plate was cleaned.   The only bad thing that happened was me dropping my spoon into the plate of curry twice. Other then that, I'm going to be getting some more curry, some Zen curry.

CvDlkLb6RgPLEkAJYQjvxw.text: An hour and a half of free time? 15 minutes away from UNLV?   I've had Japanese Curry Zen bookmarked ever since having this midnight craving for Japanese Curry and this satisfied that craving... 1 year later.   I opted for the Chicken Cutlet (my usual) and added some medium spices and it was delicious! Our Server greeted us, gave us the option to sit (there weren't many people there at the time, but was packed by the time we left)   Friendly staff and good food will make me a fan any day

iAvfaYQ6sumTBaME0TmP8A.text: Curry Zen is the newest Japanese restaurant addition to Seoul Plaza, but makes me wonder when its going to be changed to Reikon Plaza? You know Reikon meaning soul or spirit in Japanese... ah nevermind, terrible joke.   I have visited a few times now since they've opened and noticed each time the curry increases in spice slightly as well as the amount of condiments on the counter. Now they have raisins, sliced almonds, 3 different mixed spices (mild, medium, and hot of course), fukujinzuke (mixed pickled vegetables), and pickled scallions.   The menu is small ranging from chicken katsu, pork katsu, kurobata sausages, potato croquette, shrimp, a curry hot dog, and a couple of jello desserts Maybe its not their style, but if somewhere down the line they decide to add vegetables as toppings I would be all for it!  The best things about Curry Zen is the portions are good versus price (yay for college budgets), FREE brown rice option (paging brown rice warlord Misti Y), service is friendly, and I suppose that its an option for my vegetation eating friends as you can opt for the curry and a croquette.   Lastly the only con I can think of now is... where am I going to park? With  all these thriving businesses in this plaza it makes parking a chore.   A side note of the most nanoscopic size possible, I did see someone wheel in a few boxes with labels saying Java Curry. I'm not suggesting that it is not homemade, but I do wonder if they use their roux some parts of their curry? Just some thoughts from a noobs.   100th, yippee.

f7B4vq1Y6TUmAfDQCb9P9Q.text: We happened upon this place as the intended restaurant in this plaza had a long wait.  The curry dishes are super ala carte and only come with rice and your choice of meat or veggie.  But, the plus side is you can order a small portion of rice and order a bunch of add-ins, like croquette, veggies, egg, etc.  The flavor of the curry was rich and flavorful.  One each table, you can choose the level of spiciness you want, mild, hot, and extra hot by sprinking their custom peppers.  Go with the extra HOT!  As a side note, the restaurant is really small, with only a handful of tables and a counter with 6 or so seats.  Altogether, it did the job and we left satisfied.

jPzFO8WirF3DDrUAIIFRHA.text: I am very glad that we finally have a curry house in Vegas. I quickly became a regular here as soon as I discovered this spot. My favorite dishes are pork cutlet, fried shrimp and hot dog curry. You can chose white rice or brown rice to go with it. I love the crispy textures of breading of pork cutlet and fried shrimps. Pork cutlet is always juicy and never overdone. I feel fortune that they even have Japanese hot dogs on menu. This small shop is very clean and opens late. Service here is fast and efficient. It can definitely be a quick eat spot if you are in a rush.

O_2oHHXIse7z1bWewTR6Qg.text: Small store located in the same plaza as Monta Ramen and Big Wong Resturant.   I've been meaning to come here as I've heard good things from friends and others and finally was able to come.   The overall atmosphere is very friendly with a welcoming staff. I liked the atmosphere a lot. There is a bar with maybe 10 or so seats and four tables I believe that seat four each.   I'm very particular about my Japanese Curry as I am with a lot of Japanese foods, but I try to keep an open mind.   They have many condiments on the table, three of them are different levels of spicy curry powder (mild, regular, spicy), ginger, almonds, raisins, and salt & pepper. The curry powder is their recipe with many blended spices that they make.   The prices are pretty reasonable, $4.95 for the plain curry and then depending on the topping you add additional costs. You can mix and match whatever you want on their menu ranging from chicken katsu to corn and other items you would "normally" find in curry.   I got the croquette (+$2) and corn (+$1) in my plain curry. I thought for the price the croquette would be slightly larger than what it came out as, so I was a little disappointed. They brought it out on a plate with the rice on one side and curry on the other, the croquette and corn in the middle, with an overlap of curry (Japanese don't like to "mix" the curry and rice traditionally). The croquette however was good and I believe they make it as well. It was nicely browned to the correct color and breaded perfectly.   The curry itself was mediocre, maybe I was expecting more, but I have to come back and try it again to make a real comparison. The spices were good, but it felt like something was lacking, maybe it was an unlucky batch that I got. I'll definitely come back to give it another try before making a final opinion on it.   It has an authentic taste to it, maybe the most authentic out of all the curry I've tried in Las Vegas, but like I said I would have to give this another try along with some others. Will update in the near future on the taste of the curry again. =]  Oh they didn't put the ginger on the plate (thankfully, as I don't like ginger).   I would definitely recommend at least giving it a try.

UPT0zkuq6Cm7sX9MwQb37A.text: We are now regulars. We come here at least once a week for dinner and are always greeted warmly. The food is always good. I wanted to update my review because they honestly have great and fast service and the food quality is consistent. Love it!

sX0nb9rwXFbIX8lKANFHXg.text: Okay, so I went back and just ordered the curry as is, no bumps up on the spicy scale! SO MUCH BETTER this time as I was able to taste the curry all through out my meal and finished it in one go! So I would say that for first timers, just get it normal the first time so you can taste the curry and it's yummyness, then on your second try, see if you can go up a level in spice, if you so dare. XD

uuR8nXk2osjCFFa-rbdlAQ.text: Fantastic!  I like ordering different things from their menu, and so far they're all good. My favorite is the vegetable curry plate with a side of sausages. I also enjoy trying the different spice levels.  The chef is a really nice guy! He takes time to ask people how they're doing. The same goes for the rest of the staff.

0Z8yIoWCbrS74bu2hcUBxw.text: This is a medium sized local Japanese restaurant with Japanese cooks and waiter. The atmosphere is lovely and the food are yummy!

_Ty3Yjg0GQy0_G7n3vEqBQ.text: Best Japanese curry I've ever had! It was smooth, flavorful, spicy and not too salty at all. There was no wait at 9:30pm.  I had the mini curry (cheaper and still decent portion size) with pork katsu. You could tell the katsu was freshly fried. They have the fujinikjumi (sp?), the crunchy pickled red daikon on the table so you can take as much as you want. I ate half of that little pot lol.   Curry udon was also good but barely had any meat so best bang for the buck would be a rice curry dish.   Only downside is the plaza is pretty tight on parking. Even at 10:30pm people are circling around trying to find parking.

fr3QWQOykiDKW9rDGoSWIw.text: Friendly service, a pleasant n' cheery interior, and the most authentic tasting Japanese meal I've had since coming back to the States. The pork cutlet was delicious. I went for dinner on a Tuesday, and the place was empty, which makes no sense. The price and the quality of the food are fantastic. I also found out that they have wi-fi - maybe I'll return for lunch and get some work done, while enjoying some more of their yummy curry.

47wT9tqnF_q15O9ARN2oiQ.text: Good curry! great service! Ginormous portions! Easy on the piggy bank. It doesn't get better than that! I guess it's True what they say about hidden little hole in the wall's, they have the best food! My kinda place (^-^)

USXbfGli_KOQQDYqaSMo8w.text: Pork tenderloin katsu curry is the best!! Husband and I even like their katsu curry more than that of Curry House! Will come back again for sure! The katsu did take 15 mins to make but so worth the wait!! The only drawback for a big party is that it has a max occupancy of 18 and u might have a difficulty in seating all of ur party during prime time.

9TQK5AZH7PUNAIiCtVWB1Q.text: Update!!! I visited again recently and they've expanded. More room to eat, same great food and service.   This is a great curry spot in an overall cool area.  The food is great, with various levels of spice in the curry, great cutlets and with the choice of white or brown rice.  The staff is really friendly and answered each question I had.  I went twice and had a pork and a chicken katsu plate.  Each was great.  I got one at the regular, zero spice which was quite good.  I got a two a second time, and it was nicely spicy but not overpowering.  There was a great selection of drinks including sodas, canned iced teas (green and oolong) and beer and wine.  The beer is affordable with domestics being real cheap and Japanese beers being about a buck more each.  This place is a great deal and fantastic for locals or tourists.  It is close enough to the strip that you can drive over really easily.  This is a bargain compared to the usual tourist place.  I'm a big fan and plan on returning next time I'm in town.

ghirDkhAU7F4LlVyXNSe2Q.text: I was going to call this place a little hidden gem... but with over 170 reviews for a random curry house off the strip, I guess enough Yelpers have found their way over.  I went here with the bf's family before hitting the road home from a weekend in Vegas.  It is super tiny (luckily we got there before a second family, who had to go somewhere else due to lack of space).  I ordered the curry with tofu.  Others had pork, some with vegetables in the curry, and all with brown rice instead of white.  I love that they have that option.  The portions are HUGE!  My tofu was nice and crispy (I'm not pretending that's the healthier option, since "crispy" doesn't mean healthy, I just like tofu), and the curry was so flavorful and thick.  Everybody swept their plates clean!

S9Rjg9NQ4zKnJkbIgBNfQQ.text: Great authentic Japanese curry. Chicken Katsu curry with veggies, yummy!! Even the potato Croquette is delish!

M8MUmnluYLuDXbRHQyjJBw.text: finally, an authentic japanese curry joint in vegas! hooray!!! i love japanese curry so i'm totally ecstatic!  the flavor of the curry is super tasty but doesn't come in spiciness levels and i would say that it's a little too mild for me. it also doesn't contain any veggies such as carrots or potatoes which i'm sure makes no difference to most people but i must admit that i'd prefer if there was a little bit of chunkiness/thickness about the sauce.  my friend had regular white rice with his curry and, unfortunately, it was very soggy. i believe the water to rice ratio was off. it was only their 2nd day of business so i'd chalk it up as a noob mistake. i'm sure it'll be better the next time we go. i had the brown rice and it was cooked perfectly. i love the brown rice option at no additional charge.  all in all, it was satisfying and i'll most certainly be back for more. yay! i'm definitely a fan!

uLfvXADExiL-UDNIRd3KFA.text: The curry place that we were looking across the street was not open yet so we decided  on this place. Small corner shop probably enough for 15-20 people max! The menu is pretty basic. Curry, rice, and choice of meat. Don't expect anything else. The curry was really good tho. The service was good. Would definitely come back.

XWeOtryIFsUhyOXglHxG7A.text: Place is unassuming simple menu based on Japanese Curry good price.

40W8_nec6rOjHOrhUGWcKA.text: Good stuff. The price is very cheap! You can get a full bowl or a half bowl. Since I eat like a bird I opt for the half with chicken and crouquette.
